Award.AwardTitle: Beyond Drosophila: Comparative transcriptomics of schizophoran flies to resolve a rapid radiation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Large comparative studies of fly genes are currently limited to mosquitoes and the Drosophila (fruit fly) complex. Drosophila belongs to Schizophora, a group of flies with over 50,000 species that includes model organisms, disease vectors, and agricultural pests. Schizophoran phylogenetic relationships are poorly understood because flies diversified very rapidly in the past, leaving few genetic clues to decipher relationships. The investigators will use a new and innovative approach that harnesses the power of transcriptome DNA sequencing to reveal thousands of genetic clues to decipher this rapid radiation of species.

This research will generate an ortholog database that will allow other insect researchers to study genes across a wide diversity of insects. The study will advance our understanding of insect evolution by exploring the evolution of a wider range of genes. The researchers will also provide comprehensive training to a PhD student and several undergraduates in modern evolutionary research. Fly biodiversity and evolution-based outreach will be developed and presented through collaboration with Nature Research Center in Raleigh, NC. Results of the study will be used in educational materials to promote research, the understanding of evolution, and species conservation to the public and k-16.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flies are one of the largest radiations of animal life and constitute 15% of described animal species-richness on Earth. This collaborative study compiled new genomic information from transcriptomes to develop a new estimate of the evolutionary relationships among of the major groups of higher-flies and to develop a revised comprehensive classification. Genetic data are used to frame and inform tests of evolutionary hypotheses concerning the rate and pattern of species diversification and examine the implication of these findings for other organisms, especially insects. These data add to a large international effort to compare genomic data from a large number of insect species. New analysis strategies designed to handle very large datasets using high performance computing clusters  are employed to investigate evolutionary variation within the sample data.  Project data are used to extend understanding of genes that can be used in targeted gene capture methods to generate large datasets without sequencing entire genomes. Project results will allow for  estimates of  the age of origin of major fly groups during earth history using computational methods and models that help predict the origin and spread of fly lineages. The project involves academic training and a program of public outreach, with educational material disseminated through through collaborating museums and academic institutions, including development of publications, on-line videos, and resources for undergraduate and K-12 levels.
